p: Other existing drug candidates include chloroquine and camostat mesylate. Chloroquine is a widely used anti-malarial drug that is known to block virus-cell fusion and has been shown to interfere with the glycosylation of SARS-CoV and ACE-2 cellular receptors, rendering the ACE-2-SARS-CoV interaction less efficient [ 60]. There is also in vitro evidence that chloroquine may be effective in preventing SARS-CoV-2 cellular entry [ 56]. Camostat mesylate, also known as FOY 305 [ 61], was initially developed and currently approved for the treatment of chronic pancreatitis in Japan [ 62, 63]. Camostat mesylate targets the TMPRSS2 protease, theoretically preventing viral entry. Researchers in Germany showed that camostat mesylate reduced the amount of SARS-CoV-2 viral replication [ 64].
